content:
I had a weird issue with this clash. I passed all the tests in the clash but got 80% so I figured I failed a validator. So I went here to test in IDE and to my surprise I passed all the tests and validators with the same code that got me 80%.
Here's the js code:
for(n=readline(t=i=0);i++<n;k.size==(""+i).length?t++:0)k=new Set((""+i).split``)
print(t)

Edit:
Ungolfed the code a bit for readability
n=readline()
for(t=i=0;i++<n;){
  k=new Set((""+i).split``)
  k.size==(""+i).length?t++:0
}
print(t)

The final validator is significantly harder than the final test on this.

My shortest mode code in Ruby passed 100% of the tests, but then failed the last validator, using Regex on the list of integers (converted to strings) to test for a repeating digit. The tests and validators really need to be more similar, especially if you're enabling Shortest mode.

Nice clash, but the final validator needs adjustment.
My code (ungolfed):
n = gets.to_i
pattern =  /(.).*\1/
c = (1..n).count{|i| i.to_s !~ pattern }
puts c

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I have ingeniously devised a refined and effortless Ruby solution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Pretty good and simple puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good contribution.
And the tests are in an extremely wide range
did you solve it?  if so, how long did it take you?
Yes, i solve it. idk know how much time exactly but around 1min or 2min
